title: How to improve my math grades in high school as a teenager - Quora

response.answer_text: Make sure you read questions correctly and go backwards after finding an answer to make sure it’s right. I’ve made so many stupid mistakes on test, some of it even because I’ve read my own hand-writing wrong sometimes (and this has cost me many points over the years). Do whatever homework is assigned by your math teacher- the homework is usually designed to help you, and at least in my experience the math homework I’ve received in my last two years of school have not been busy work but have actually helped. If necessary, you can even go ask your teacher for help. That is exactly what they are there for- to teach you. If you aren’t understanding a certain concept or need help, then ask them after trying to find the solution yourself (if you are unable to do so or are unsure how to reach the right answer).

Practice, practice, and practice. I can only emphasize how important and effective it really is to practice. Don't practice math problems within your comfort zone. Step out of it, and challenge yourself to overcoming the difficulties you face in math. If you are going to waste time and practice on the things you feel comfortable with i.e 1+1, its not going to take you anywhere. Google for practice papers w. mark-schemes that match your current level. The web has a wealth of info. Do the papers, then grade yourself with the corresponding mark-sheme. Oh, and please don't cheat yourself, as this really requires a great deal of self-discipline. Finally, here is a formula for success I would like to share. Hard-work + commitment + persistence = success Results take time and patience mate. You cant get what you want immediately by plucking leaves off a tree.

Alright, as with anything you must practice. although there may be only one mathematical principle used to solve problems, there's most likely “loop holes”. By this I mean that maybe you can't use your mathematical principle until you algebraically rearrange your equation/function. Practicing also helps for test day when it helps to be able to recall a particular problem that was worked similar to the one on the test. I've made plenty of mistakes due to misreading/not reading the full problem statement, so I've started to look through my tests once I finish and if I have time even rework the problems to verify my answer. If it is show your work….SHOW YOUR WORK!!!! Get that partial credit! Even if you don't have a clue what's going on, make something up that sounds kinda right and maybe you'll be closer to the right answer than you think (closer than a blank answer for sure). CAUTION: don't ‘memorize’, learn. Understand. Even if you see a problem on your homework that looks hard and dissimilar to the examples you've been given, try to work it. You'll learn more because you had to think through the process of what you did for the other problems and then learn why this particular problem had to be worked different.
